newsitem.title: UK: BBA profit growth fuelled by acquisitions.
newsitem.headline: BBA profit growth fuelled by acquisitions.

text.p: Engineering concern BBA Group Plc unveiled a 19 percent leap in six month pretax pre-exceptional profits on Wednesday, fuelled by continued expansion growth.
BBA saw profits for the first half of 1996 rise to 72.1 million stg, with the interim dividend at 2.1 pence per share, up from 1.8.
Turnover was up 24 percent for continuing operations at 552.4 million stg, flattered by acquisition sales. Stripping that out, factor sales were up five percent at 469 million stg.
In a divisional breakdown, BBA said transportation's friction unit had enjoyed a good period in the face of tough market conditions in Germany.
The unit is seen benefiting from its investment programme and further efficiency gains later in the year.
New business came from car-makers including and Nissan.
The U.S. arm also continued to expand, with plant capacity set to double to keep up with demand.
The UK landing gear business had a good first half, together with the Texstars aircraft canopy unit.
Both divisions returned to profit and are set to continue to benefit from the upturn in aerospace.
In the industrial sector of the group, non-woven products performed in line with forecasts, with operating margins and market shares improving.
The filtration business is seen affording more growth potential this year. This, plus sound sales and the easing of raw material costs pointed to encouraging prospects ahead.
The specialist electrical business saw profits and sales move ahead, with the order book looking strong and increasing penetration in the Asia Pacific region.
